Inclusion criteria: Clinical or pathological confirmation of the diagnosis of B-NHL at any risk group according to the Rai staging system. Previously untreated B-cell NHL: - High-grade lymphoma according to the modified Durie-Salmon grading system. - Stage 1 or 2 NHLSF/EORTC according to the International Prognostic Index (IPI). - Measurable disease according to the REAL score. - Lymphocyte doubling time > 1.5 months as measured from a single previous remission assessment. - Performance status (PS) 0 or 1. Previously treated B-cell NHL: - Relapse at any site after any number of previous therapies for B-cell NHL irrespective of duration of remission and type of treatment including transplantation. - Lymphocyte doubling time > 1.5 months. - PS 0 or 1. Exclusion criteria: - No prior stem cell transplant. - Severe comorbidity as defined by the following criteria: - Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status greater than 3. - Any grade III to IV toxicity after previous treatment. - Major or frequent (grade II) cardiac, pulmonary, or liver disease. - Known active CNS disease or a history of CNS disease with evidence of uncontrolled CNS prophylaxis. - Known active endocrine disease: Diabetes mellitus, thyroid disease, or severe psoriasis. - Serious bleeding. - Female patients not wishing to take oral contraceptives. - Inability to understand or comply with the study procedures. - Major gastrointestinal ulceration. - Active, uncontrolled infections. - Pregnant or breastfeeding women. - Any other disease or condition the investigator considers to be likely to prevent compliance with the trial procedures or that might impair the interpretation of the study results. Exclusion of previous trial treatment in previous NHL: - Documented evidence of relapse after previous treatment for CLL, low-grade NHL or small lymphocytic lymphoma. - Known positive test for HIV. - Sensitive or active autoimmune disorders.

model_response: The study design is a phase 1b/2 clinical trial. Phase 1b trials typically test a new agent in a small number of people to determine what dose is safe and tolerable. Phase 2 trials test a new agent in a bigger group of people to determine if it is effective in treating the disease. A phase 2 trial like the one described uses a control group to compare the safety and effectiveness of the new agent with the standard treatment for the disease. For this trial, the control arm is standard of care for patients with metastatic uveal melanoma, which is a combination of intravenous (IV) fluids and intravitreal (into the eye) chemotherapy for patients with evidence of central nervous system and/or liver metastasis. We also have a group of participants receiving the combination of Ziv-Aflibercept and Cemiplimab, which is the investigational arm.
This study design was chosen to maximize drug exposure while using the least number of injections and infusions.

This protocol aims to compare the efficacy and safety of ondansetron given weekly and daily for nausea and vomiting associated with PD-1 inhibitor therapy. The safety and efficacy of aprepitant as a 125mg oral tablet administered on day 1 of each 3-week treatment cycle will also be assessed.
Pre-treatment with standard of care PD-1 and / or PD-L1 inhibitor therapy will be allowed. The duration of treatment with the Weekly Ondansetron and Aprepitant (wOAA) study will be 32 weeks for patients randomized to the study. Patients will undergo a screening assessment followed by 8 assessment visits and a Follow-up assessment at 4 weeks after the last dose of study treatment. Blood will be drawn for safety labs, concomitant medication assessments, adverse event tracking, and pharmacokinetics on every assessment visit. An additional 3 blood draws will be performed in patients who experience vomiting or an adverse event that leads to discontinuation of ondansetron and a subsequent restart on a lower dose. Vital signs and physical examination will be performed at each visit. Adverse events and concomitant medication use will be monitored through 30 days after treatment. The first dose of ondansetron and ondansetron dose escalation will occur at screening and during weeks 2 and 6, respectively. Dexamethasone dose escalation will occur at weeks 4, 12, 16 and 20.

By including a placebo group, we can evaluate if the symptoms improved by 608 actually represent a treatment effect or are due to placebo effects. 6.5 RATIONALE FOR DOSE Finding the optimal dose of a drug for use in clinical studies requires clinical experience and a thorough understanding of how drugs are absorbed, metabolized, and eliminated by the body. Phase I pharmacokinetic studies can be done early in the discovery process before large scale drug development begins. Dose-A pharmacokinetic studies are useful for determining the dose and route of administration of a new drug in order to reach therapeutic plasma levels consistent with efficacy. The objective of a Phase I dose-a, pharmacokinetic study is to achieve measurable drug plasma concentrations against which dose-efficacy relationships can be established in subsequent nonclinical or clinical studies. It is typically used when only a preliminary formulation is available and a final formulation requires optimization. To be considered effective, a new drug must have adequate bioavailability and its maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) must be greater than the minimum effective concentration (Cm). Bioavailability can be increased by decreasing its rate of absorption or increasing its volume of distribution. A sufficient dose for human Phase 1 use is that which results in a concentration that is 2- to 10-fold higher than the human equivalent of the optimal dose for a particular species used for preclinical testing. Maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) must be at least 30% higher than that seen with the minimum effective dose. Dose-a studies help determine whether: Increasing the dose of a drug increases or decreases the concentration of the drug in the bloodstream Increasing the size of a drug particle increases or decreases the drug concentration in the bloodstream Changing the formulation of a drug (e.g. tablet to injectable formulation) decreases or increases the concentration in the blood If the drug is absorbed slowly from the gastrointestinal tract, it is advantage

Of course. In the first arm, the intervention is the Rex implants with a machined transcortical portion and bone consumption and expansion procedures. In the second arm, the intervention is the Rex implants with a roughened transcortical portion and the same bone consumption and expansion procedures.

Yes, of course. Both study arms will receive Rex implants with a machined transcortical portion. For the bone consumption procedure, we will use a high-speed tapping technique. This has been shown to be a safe and predictable method for removing bone in preparation for implant placement. In the bone expansion procedure, we will use a high-speed surgical drill to create a channel in the edentulous bone and insert the implant at a specific angle and torque. The roughened surface of the implant will help it to better integrate with the bone, resulting in a stronger attachment and a more natural look and feel. The comparison between the two treatment modalities will help us determine which results in better clinical and radiographic outcomes.

Certainly. The control arm will receive treatment as usual, which will consist of the placement of implants and prosthetic abutments and loading with a provisional prosthesis or temporary restoration. The experimental arm will receive treatment as in the control arm but will receive Ridge Expansion and Apex Reduction with either a machined transcortical or roughened transcortical surface. The machined transcortical surface will be tested to see if micro-machining of the implant shaft has an effect on clinical and radiological predictability of the implant in narrow ridges. The roughened surface group will be tested to determine the effect of a roughened surface for the narrow ridge application in order to test if surface texturing of the implant increases implant osseointegration for narrow ridges.  After placement of the implants, patients will be followed-up at regular intervals for a period of at least one year post-operatively, at which time radiographs and clinical photos will be taken and measurements of bone and soft tissue levels at implant level will be taken. The radiographic data will be evaluated at the time of placement and at regular intervals post placement, at one, two and three months, and annually until the end of the one year follow-up period at which time the final radiographs and evaluation will be performed.

So, according to the literature, Maitland's mobilization technique involves high-velocity, low-amplitude, and long-arc movements. For the interferential therapy, we can use either low-frequency or high-frequency current, either with or without local heat application, with each treatment session lasting 15-20 minutes. Does that sound acceptable to you? ​

Interferential therapy involves the use of two electrical currents of different frequencies and intensities being delivered to the affected area. These currents produce a pulsed, noxious, tingling sensation that activates the body's natural painkillers. Interferential therapy is thought to promote blood flow to the affected region, thereby accelerating tissue repair. Patients in the experimental group will receive interferential therapy on the affected knee.
Mulligan's mobilization technique consists of five components: log rolling, knee passive stretch, cross fiber, anterior glide, posterior glide, and compression.

The parameters for interferential therapy in the active comparator group are similar to that of the interventional arm, except for an increase in current intensity and a decrease in frequency. The current intensity should be set at the level where the subject feels a strong tingling sensation but not muscle contraction, and the treatment duration can be varied based on the needs of the patient. The sweep frequency should be set at 10 to 130 Hz.

Sure. The study design is as follows: Study Arm A: Mobilization with movement (MWM) - Maitland versus MWM + Interferential therapy (MWM + IFT) Study Arm B: Manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) - Maitland versus MUA + Interferential therapy (MUA + IFT) (Study Comparators: MWM, MUA)  The study consists of one within-subjects factor in which the two study arms (MWM, MUA) will be compared within the two comparator groups (MWM and MUA).  The study period of two weeks should be long enough for clinical and physiological changes following each intervention to take place. The study should be repeated by other investigators.
A randomized controlled trial in the effect of interferential therapy on outcomes of maitland (MWM) and manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) techniques on knee osteoarthritis patients.
One session per week for two weeks. Treatment will be performed by trained physical therapists.
Primary outcome measures assessed at 1 week (W0) and 2 weeks (W2) and include pain using a 11-point numeric rating scale (NRS 11); function assessed using a knee range of motion (ROM) and knee disability and osteoarthritis index (OAI).
Secondary measures of pain assessed at W0 and W2 include: - Visual analogue scale (VAS) for pain (0-100 mm) - Knee injury and osteoarthritis society (KOOS): pain (0-100) - Euroques questionnaire (EQ 5D-5L).  Secondary measures of function include: Quality of life measure as measure of health using KOOS; Tegner activity performance (TAP) and Timed up and go test (TUG) knee disability measures.

model_response: What is the population of interest?

A randomized double blinded controlled clinical trial protocol design is as follows: 1. Seventy patients with the primary diagnosis of fibromyalgia will be recruited from outpatient department of the hospital. 2. After obtaining informed consent, patients will be randomly allocated in a 1:1 ratio into one of two groups: Experimental group and control group. 3. Experimental group will be administered the Pain Modulation Index test, followed by the Pain Detection and the Central Sensitivity Inventory questionnaires. Control group will be administered only the questionnaires. 4. Patients in both groups will have six weeks to complete assessments. 5. Patients will be contacted by phone one or two weeks after their final assessment to determine if they have experienced any changes in their pain. 6. Patients will be asked to complete the Visual Analog Scale to evaluate pain after two and four weeks. 7. Data will be analyzed using SPSS software, with a two tailed alpha set at 0.05 and a power set at 0.80. 8. In the case of an urgent need to discontinue treatment for any safety reason, patients in both groups will undergo treatment as guided by the treating physician. 9. The data collected from the two groups will be compared using the independent t-test or the Mann-Whitney test, and a p-value of less than 0.05 will be considered statistically significant. 10. The study coordinator will not be permitted to interpret the results or act as a potential reviewer. 11. The study will be submitted to the ethics committee of our hospital for approval. A copy of the submitted study protocol will be provided to the committee for their review. The trial will begin once approval is granted. 12. At the end of the study, results will be published in a peer-reviewed journal. 13. In the case of any unforeseen adverse events, the trial will be stopped immediately. Thank you for your assistance with this matter. I look forward to working with you.

Designing the Analysis Plan ↑
After defining the study arms and inclusion and exclusion criteria in the previous section, we can move on to designing the analysis plan, or study protocol, for the mock study. The analysis plan is an important part of the study protocol, as it describes how we will actually analyze the data collected. In clinical research, the analysis plan is usually broken down into several stages, each with its own protocol.
The analysis plan should address the research question being asked, how the data will be analyzed to answer the research question, and what outcomes will be compared to determine the answer. For example, in our mock study on participation rates in clinical trials by gender and age group, the analysis plan could include a statistical analysis of data from the included patients, broken down by gender and age group, to determine the difference in participation rates between each group. A confidence interval can be calculated to determine the precision and accuracy of the data, and statistics such as Pearson's chi-squared test or Student's t-test may be used to analyze the data. Based on the results, a conclusion can be drawn as to whether there are significant differences in participation rates by gender or age group. The full analysis plan should be outlined in detail in the study protocol.
It's important to remember that the analysis plan may change during the course of a study, as new information or challenges arise during data collection. It's also important to note that the study protocol should be thorough, comprehensive and clearly written, to ensure all research team members and external parties understand the protocol and plan of action.
Communicating the Results ↑
The final step in the mock study is to communicate the results to relevant stakeholders. Depending on the nature of the study, the results may be presented at a scientific conference, published in a peer-reviewed journal, or given to industry or governmental departments as part of a grant report. Presenting results in an academic setting may require an abstract, presentation, or poster, while publishing in a peer-reviewed journal will require a full manuscript. A grant

Role of Statistical Analysis in Clinical Trials
In this activity, you reviewed the roles of inclusion and exclusion criteria in clinical studies. Can we do better than that? We hope so! We reviewed the sample size calculation formula in a previous module to determine how well an existing study design would recruit enough participants to answer the research question. Here, we are going to go a step further to ask if enough patients with the disease of interest will be included in this trial, and how we can improve the success of the study by minimizing the dropouts. In the context of clinical trials, we use statistical analysis to assess whether the difference in treatment effect between treatment groups (e.g., drug vs. placebo or competing drug) is statistically significant. The statistical analysis used is often a t-test or analysis of variance (ANOVA), and this is why they are referred to as clinical endpoints. In addition, the effect size or power of the study can also be determined using this analysis. For example, if the drug being studied has a large effect, and we want to see a large difference in drug treatments, we will need more subjects in each group to answer our research question. However, if the effect size of the drug is small, we might only need to recruit approximately half of the patients per group to get the answer. Therefore, we need to calculate the effect size or power of the study to know how much samples are needed. This is how statistical analysis is essential in a clinical study.

model_response: Sure thing! Part A would be the escalation arm, in which eligible participants are first administered Tepotinib alone. This is designed to help us establish a pharmacokinetic baseline of the drug in the participants' bodies. If a participant has promising responses, such as stable disease or even a complete response, they would be crossed over to the expansion arm, where they receive Tepotinib in combination with Pembrolizumab. The intention is to assess the safety and efficacy of the combination treatment. It's important to note that participants on the escalation arm will be removed from the study if they experience unacceptable toxicity or disease progression.

In Part B - Expansion, we will enroll patients who have received one or more lines of systemic anticancer therapy for advanced NSCLC. This arm will help us evaluate the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab. We will first evaluate safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacogenomics at a lower dose. If all is well, we will then escalate to the next dose to assess efficacy.

We propose to administer Tepotinib as an oral daily treatment at various doses initially, then the dose will be escalated every three weeks until we see any dose-limiting toxicity or disease progression. For the expansion study, Pembrolizumab will be given as an intravenous infusion every three weeks until intolerability or disease progression.

In Part B - Expansion, patients with MET exon 14 skipping mutations will receive Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab in the same dosage as in Part A - Escalation, but for a longer duration of 12 weeks. The combination will then be administered for 21 days, followed by a dose-level escalation of Tepotinib if necessary. The final dose of Pembrolizumab will be determined by biological disease progression.

The intervention entails the use of EUS to deliver a lumen-apposing metal stent (LAMS) for the treatment of benign gallbladder pathology, including cholelithiasis, chronic calculous cholecystitis, and cholecystitis. When needed, endoscopic lithotripsy will be used to fragment gallstones, which may inhibit stent-jumping and facilitate the procedure.  EUS-guided gallbladder manipulation by ultrasound imaging is minimally invasive, bloodless, and without the risks involved in laparoscopic or open surgery.  In addition, because no dissection of the gallbladder is needed during EUS or endoscopic lithotripsy, the risk of short and long-term complications are minimized.  Compared to laparoscopic cholectomy, EUS-guided therapy is technically simpler, with a shorter postoperative recovery period and in-hospital stay.   However, because of the learning curve associated with this emerging endoscopic technique, surgical intervention may not be feasible for the current pilot study and we must proceed with endoscopic therapy instead.  Endoscopic lithotripsy is a relatively new method used to fragment stones that cannot be safely removed by the stent, and its efficacy is unknown at this time.  This is the first EUS-guided gallbladder intervention performed in the United States.

model_response: The experimental arm is the "Internet-Behavioral Cough Suppression Therapy" arm. Participants in this arm will be asked to watch treatment-specific educational and training videos and perform the training exercises as recommended. The treatment protocol will be provided by a certified provider and will occur remotely via secure videoconferencing applications. Treatment will last for 5 weeks and all of the material will be downloadable for the participant's reference at any time during the study period. Participants will be required to keep a log during the therapy period and complete periodic online surveys about side effects and symptoms. All communications with the provider will be electronic. The control arm is the sham comparator treatment. Participants in this arm will receive the sham iBCST therapy materials but no treatment. They will be directed to watch the tutorial videos and complete the exercises as directed but no further involvement will be provided. They will be asked to keep a log during the therapy period and complete periodic surveys about side effects and symptoms. All communications with the provider will be via secure messaging.

In the sham comparator arm, participants will have access to the same number of treatment videos at the same intervals as the experimental arm, but the videos will be unrelated to the treatment being offered in the experimental arm. There will be no instructions to complete exercises or questions to monitor adherence. This is to ensure that any effects seen in the study are a result of the experimental treatment and not a placebo effect.

This study intends to measure the effects of the Internet-Behavioral Cough Suppression Therapy, or iCST. However, it's also important to have a sham comparator intervention in place to test the placebo effect. By comparing the two, we can better measure the treatment's true success in reducing cough frequency and severity.

[/instrument] Many observational studies and some randomized controlled trials use a crossover design to evaluate exposure-response relationships. A crossover study is an example of an observational study that incorporates an intervention. Many crossover studies also randomize subjects to different treatment groups at a single time point, so they have elements of a cross-over, parallel-group randomized controlled trial. You can use the "Split-plot" tool to create this type of design.
There may be some cases where you want to compare the efficacy of two treatments using a within-subject design where each subject is their own control or where each subject receives both treatments. To do this, you can use the "Crossover" tool and set the entry into the within-subject factor as the treatment of interest and the exit from the factor as the control or contrast treatment. The default setting for the within-subject factor is 2x2 but you can change it to suit your needs. Then, just choose a block size that will provide an adequate number of treatment-control pairs.
For example, we could use a 2x2 within-subject crossover design with a block size of 2 to compare two treatments: 1) treatment #1: drug A, and 2) treatment #2: no treatment.
When the same subject is given both treatments, some factors need to be fixed and other factors are randomized. The fixed factors are the subject and treatment factors since every subject receives both treatments. The random factors would be the blocks and within-subject factors; in this case, the treatment-control crossover. 4. Recruitment and Retention 4.1 Recruitment and Retention. (Continued) 4.1.5 Recruitment Finding qualified, eligible subjects who meet the criteria for enrollment in the trial is crucial to the success of a clinical study. Competent and energetic study staff with in-depth knowledge of the protocol and the disease under investigation are essential to enrolling study subjects as rapidly and effectively as possible. Well-publicized advertisements aimed at the target population are helpful in identifying subjects. Subjects are often recruited through the collaboration of the study physician and an advertising and marketing firm, although the principal physician or specialist involved with a study usually is responsible for initiating and continually monitoring subject enrollment. Sponsors may use either the "head-research-site" model or the "centralized-recruitment" model for subject recruitment. In the "head-research-site" model, sponsors place their field personnel to work with investigators and their study staff at each research site and subject enrollment occurs at the site from sponsor-proposed screening and eligibility criteria, thereby assuring rapid study start-up and enrollment and assuring uniformity in study conduct. In the "centralized-recruitment" model, prospective subjects are solicited from media ads and are submitted to a central location for screening by a centralized screening unit prior to enrollment into the study. Investigators can use either model. If the centralized system is used, subject flow is monitored by the principal investigators and sponsor through frequent phone calls, site visits, and regular reporting. 4.1.6 Recruiting Ethnically Diverse Populations When conducting a multicenter study in the United States, the study sponsor is required to implement procedures for the collection of data on race and ethnicity, in addition to collecting specific gender data, in order to satisfy current Federal requirements (FDA, HIPAA, DHHS and DNI). model_response: That sounds like an interesting product. What will be its dose and formulation?
I see. And may I know the hypothesis that you are testing in your trial?

In randomized trials, the balance of baseline covariates between treatment groups.
Latent outcome
Outcome (or effect) is not a directly observed phenomenon, but instead assumed.
Laypersons fallacy
Fallacy of assuming that the sample statistics summarize the underlying population characteristics even when not known to do so.
Measurement bias
Systematic error introduced during the measurement process.
Open-label
Intervention is clearly identifiable to participants within the study. In an observational cohort, exposure is known at baseline, so that individuals know if they are in the exposed or unexposed group.
Crossover studies with non-identical intervention groups. Treatment group allocation is unknown to the subject and the experimenters.
Withdrawal bias
The phenomenon in which participants or researchers know which treatment group is receiving the intervention, and therefore behave differently within the study.
In clinical trials, an adverse event or adverse effect that has its onset after the decision to stop randomizing new patients to one or both study groups.

In this arm, patients will receive an infusion of dexmedetomidine, which is a positive allosteric agonist of alpha2-adrenergic receptors, at 1 to 2 mg/hr infused over 12 hours. Dexmedetomidine has been shown to be effective in controlling pain and pr edisposition for mechanical ventilation in patients with multiple trauma, and it has a more predictable adverse effects profile than morphine. Sure thing! There are two additional study arms. Patients in this arm will act as their own control for comparison with the other two groups so that any changes in pain management strategies between hospitals or periods will not confound the results.
